clinical_study.brief_title: SARS-CoV-2 Infection Among Health Care Workers
clinical_study.official_title: Associated Factors in the Transmission and Dynamics of SARS-CoV-2 Infection Among Health Care Workers in Hospitals on the Islands of Santiago and São Vicente in Cabo Verde

collaborator.agency: Institute of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, NOVA University, Lisbon, Portugal
National Institute of Public Health of Cape Verde, Praia, Cape Verde
Centro de Investigacao em Saude de Manhica
European and Developing Countries Clinical Trials Partnership (EDCTP)

brief_summary.textblock: The present study finds opportunities and justifications, taking into consideration that the nature of professional practice in health needs scientific evidence resulting from systematic and systemic studies to strengthen the basis for the decisions made to have an impact on various levels, from the patient to health management itself. In addition, Cabo Verdean authorities may benefit from new evidence obtained by this study. It intends, in a growing number of health professionals exposed or infected with SARS-CoV-2, involved at the front line, in the different health structures of the country, to contribute to substantiate a better perception of the problem and the required solutions. Therefore, assessing the potential risk factors for SARS-CoV-2 infection among healthcare workers will be essential to characterize virus transmission, preventing future infections in them and providing the associated healthcare. Due to the advances and important changes described, questions arise that guide this research and allow us to identify the problem.

detailed_description.textblock:
The problem is stated in the following starting questions:
- What conditions are associated with infection and non-infection by SARS-CoV-2 among health professionals working in the three hospitals on the islands of Santiago and São Vicente? Who are they (gender, age group, profession, type of contact, etc)? Where do they work (sector)? When and how did the infection occur?
- What is the frequency of antibody presence in professionals with confirmed SARS-CoV-2 infection?
- How long do anti-SARS-CoV-2 antibodies last?
- What is the impact of infection on unplanned absenteeism?
- What complaints persist after SARS-CoV-2 infection?

primary_outcome.description: Time from infection to presence of Anti-SARS-CoV-2 antibodies
Time from duration of Anti-SARS-CoV-2 Antibodies

primary_outcome.measure: Total number of days absent from work due to COVID-19
primary_outcome.description: Absenteeism due to COVID-19 related symptoms

arm_group.description: Professionals who report positive SARS-CoV-2 infection confirmed by performing a positive PCR test and/or positive Rapid Antigen Test in the period prior to the interview
Professionals who report no SARS-CoV-2 infection by either of the cited methods in the period prior to the interview and/or suspected COVID-19 in the period prior to the interview

intervention.description: Capillary blood collection, for diagnosis of anti-SARS-CoV-2 Antibodies by rapid test, will be done at the first interview, for all controls. Collection of peripheral venous blood, in the cradle area, for analysis of the presence and duration of anti-SARS-CoV-2 Antibodies will be done at the first interview, and after 3 and 6 months from selection, for all cases. The serological diagnosis consists of testing for Anti-SARS-CoV-2 antibodies in a blood sample, and whole blood, plasma, or serum can be used. The tests of choice will be based on the principle of immunoassay by immunochromatography and/or ELISA.

study_pop.textblock:
The population of the study is composed of health professionals working in the Hospitals of the islands of Santiago and S. Vicente.
In addition to measuring infection-related exposures, specific SARS-CoV-2 infection-related parameters will also be assessed for cases, including presence and duration of anti-SARS-CoV-2 antibodies; absenteeism due to infection; and self-reported symptomatology due to SARS-CoV-2/ COVID-19 infection. Cases will additionally be followed up for a period of 6 months to measure unplanned, infection-related absenteeism and illness-related symptomatology.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Being a healthcare professional working in one of the hospitals where the study will take place
- Be aged ≥18 years;
- Cases: SARS-CoV-2 infection confirmed by PCR test and/or Rapid Antigen Test;
- Control: Negative rapid test for anti-SARS-CoV-2 antibodies.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Case: Confirmation of diagnosis test for SARS-CoV-2 without indication of specimen collection date.
- Control: Suspected SARS-CoV-2 infection.
